Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds "AJ" (Wendy) Harris of Oklahoma State University to conduct a research project, entitled "How many species of buckeye trees exist in China?" during the summer of 2012 at Zhejiang University in Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China. The host scientist is Professor Chengxin Fu.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to resolve the current uncertainty regarding the number, diversity, and geographic extent of Chinese species of buckeye trees, Aesculus L. Thus, the research contributes to a better understanding of plant diversity in China. While preliminary, this study is expected to facilitate future collection efforts by identifying locations of populations and to generate interest in further work on Chinese species of Aesculus, including the development of Aesculus as a model system for better understanding the modern distribution and composition of Northern Hemisphere temperate forests.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to resolve uncertainties regarding the number, diversity, and geographic extent of buckeye tree species in China. I expect that my results will ultimately inform future efforts to locate and conserve populations of these iconic trees within China and the eastern Asian region.

My specific research objectives were two-fold.  First, I proposed to construct a molecular genealogy of buckeyes that I collected in the field and at botanical gardens. I expected individual buckeyes of each species to have closer relationships to one another than to other species. Thus, I anticipated that species would form clusters or clades within the genealogy. Second, I proposed to quantify macroscopic characteristics of buckeye museum specimens and to analyze them statistically. I expected unique species to possess statistically discrete suites of characteristics and, thus, for specimens to be clustered into species groups.

Towards accomplishing my objectives, I collected specimens from two field sites and three botanical gardens, performed basic molecular laboratory work for all collected samples, and visited eight museums to view and photograph buckeye collections. I also began measuring macroscopic characteristics of buckeye museum specimens by performing image analyses of the photographs that I took.

The NSF-EAPSI China fellowship experience presented me with the opportunity to develop long term professional connections with my host, Professor Chengxin Fu of Zhejiang University, his students, and faculty at South China Botanical Gardens, Kunming Botanical Institute, Sichuan University, and the Beijing National Herbarium. Further, I was able to meet a collaborator at Sichuan University for the first time in person. Our meeting helped to solidify our intentions to pursue future projects together. In addition to professional networking opportunities, the fellowship provided me with my first experience in designing a research project to be conducted at a foreign host lab.

I expect that my scientific results will be published in a peer reviewed journal article before the end of 2013 Moreover, I anticipate using my photographs and other data to design an activity for middle school age girls to be presented at the EPSCOR women in science conference.
